lines.text: I don't use a pen. I write with a goose quill dipped in venom.
I can afford a blemish on my character, but not on my clothes.
[first lines]

[narrating off screen]
I shall never forget the weekend Laura died. A silver sun burned through the sky like a huge magnifying glass. It was the hottest Sunday in my recollection. I felt as if I were the only human being left in New York. For with Laura's horrible death, I was alone. I, Waldo Lydecker, was the only one who really knew her, and I had just begun to write Laura's story when another of those detectives came to see me. I had him wait. I could watch him through the half-open door.
[clock chimes]
I noted that his attention was fixed upon my clock. There was only one other in existence, and that was in Laura's apartment, in the very room where she was murdered.
I don't know a lot about anything, but I know a little about practically everything.
Love is eternal. It has been the strongest motivation for human actions throughout history. Love is stronger than life. It reaches beyond the dark shadow of death.
I must say, for a charming, intelligent girl, you certainly surrounded yourself with a remarkable collection of dopes.
You'd better watch out, McPherson, or you'll finish up in a psychiatric ward. I doubt they've ever had a patient who fell in love with a corpse.

My dear, either you were born on a extremely rustic community, where good manners are unknown, or you suffer from a common feminine delusion that the mere fact of being a woman exempts you from the rules of civilized conduct.
I suspect nobody and everybody.
I forgot to tell you, I also read palms, I swallow swords, I mend my own socks, I never eat garlic or onions, what more could you want of a man?

[about the list of suspects]
You know you are on the list too.
Good. It would insult me to be overlooked.
When a dame gets killed, she doesn't worry about how she looks.
Will you stop calling her a dame?
In my case, self-absorption is completely justified. I have never discovered any other subject quite so worthy of my attention.
I'm not kind, I'm vicious. It's the secret of my charm.
I cannot stand these morons any longer. If you don't come with me this instant, I shall run amok.
I knew there was something on my mind. Ah yes, will you dine with me tomorrow night?
Yes.
No, it's not that - it's the next night. And what about three weeks from tonight? And all the nights in between?
Shelby, you talk as if I had no other engagements!
And two months from now? And the month after that?
What about next year?
Oh, that's all settled. What about breakfast?
What about dancing?
What about lunch? Beautiful lunches, day after day after day?
[last lines]
Goodbye, Laura.

[narrating off screen]
Goodbye, my love.
Murder is my favorite crime.
How singularly innocent I look this morning.
Yeah, dames are always pulling a switch on you.
I should be sincerely sorry to see my neighbor's children devoured by wolves.

The famous and the infamous. Her youth and beauty, her poise and charm of manner captivated them all. She had warmth, vitality. She had authentic magnetism. Wherever we went, she stood out. Men admired her; women envied her. She became as famous as Waldo Lydecker's walking stick and his white carnation.
Nice little place you have here, Mr. Lydecker.
It's lavish, but I call it home.
On Saturday when our men went to the hotel to tell you that Laura Hunt was dead you seemed sincerely shocked.
I was. I hadn't expected that mistake.
But you had your alibi ready no matter who was dead.
I just dropped in to inquire about the state of your health? Insipid, I hope.
For the last time, Louise, will you marry me?
No, but I cooked some chicken liver for you.
If you come a little bit closer, my boy, I can just crack your skull with my walking stick.
Have you ever been in love?
A doll in Washington Heights once got a fox fur outta me.
I suspect nobody and everybody. I am strictly trying to get at the truth.
Let's not be psychiatric. But in a word, yes.

[Explaining why she broke a promise]
You forced me to give you my word. I never have been and I never will be bound by anything I don't do of my own free will.

[to McPherson after he walks through the door unannounced]
Haven't you heard of science's newest triumph, the doorbell?
I ain't afraid of cops. I was brought up to spit whenever I saw one.
OK, go ahead and spit if that'll make you feel better.
By stooping so low you only degrade yourself.
